title: Coco Gauff Is the Future of American Tennis. But It Still Looks Bleak on the Men’s Side.
text:
Every year American men play at all four Grand Slam singles events, and every year American men lose. Andy Roddick was the last U.S. man to win a major title, 16 years ago in 2003. And everyone agrees that this drought will likely continue, with no stars on the horizon.

It’s an annoying and frustrating problem, but there’s a simple answer. Men’s tennis needs someone like Cori “Coco” Gauff.

“To have a guy like Coco would be huge, and participation, my guess is, will go up,” said Jose Higueras, a long-time coach who works with the U.S. Tennis Association Player Development team.

But while Gauff is buoying interest from all fans—and maybe even persuading some teenage boys there is a path to stardom beyond more popular sports like basketball—the USTA can’t just wish a boy version of Coco into existence.

In America, there hasn’t been a men’s player who seems a sure bet since Roddick, who retired in 2012. There is one player, John Isner, who remains inside the top 15 on the ATP Tour (he is 34 years old). Sam Querrey, 31, is now No. 46. Frances Tiafoe, age 21, was at No. 29 earlier this year, the best of his career. But he has since fallen and is now at No. 45. Donald Young Jr. showed promise, but, at age 30, he has never been ranked higher than No. 38 (that was in 2012). Two other players—Taylor Fritz, 21, and Reilly Opelka, 22—have had some success, but they have accomplished little at the Slams.

“Some of these big guys have been struggling,” John McEnroe said. “They’re dangerous, but I don’t think they could be winning majors. We’re in a frustrating period that’s continuing. Hopefully that will change sooner rather than later.”

Reilly Opelka reacts during a break in play against Dominik Koepfer during the second round of the U.S. Open. Photo: Adam Hunger/Associated Press

American women players continue to thrive. There are fewer opportunities for young, athletically gifted American girls than boys, and nothing is as popular—and possibly as remunerating—as tennis. American women have dominated for decades, with Serena Williams at the top as she tries to win her 24th Grand Slam title.

But young American men have other options, such as basketball, hockey, baseball, football and soccer. In other countries, such as Serbia and Spain, tennis is among the most popular sports entertainment. In the United States, tennis communities might spread out too thin.

That’s why Gauff matters so much. When she played at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday night, she and her opponent Naomi Osaka sold out the event. For America, Gauff looks like the first true phenom since Venus and Serena Williams became stars after Serena won her first major title in 1999.

“I think [Gauff] is just incredibly talented,” Serena Williams said. “Anyone that’s 15 playing like that, people are going to be drawn to them. I think that’s pretty awesome.”

American men once ruled professional tennis. Since Richard Sears won a tournament in the 1880s, the country has been consistent. Arthur Ashe won the U.S. Open in 1968. Jimmy Connors, McEnroe and Michael Chang won major titles in the 1970s and 1980s. In the 1990s, Pete Sampras, Andre Agassi and Jim Courier were dominant, with Sampras winning 14 major titles by 2002, a year before Roger Federer won his first. Roddick won just one Slam title, but there were other players ranked high, such as James Blake (No. 4 in 2006) and Mardy Fish (No. 7 in 2011). Both Isner and Querrey have reached major semifinals, but no one has matched Roddick’s last final in 2009.

Some complain that the USTA hasn’t done enough to inspire young boys.

“There is really no domestic pathway for competitive boys in tennis in America, either in college tennis or pro tennis,” said Geoff Grant, a longtime tennis parent who recently completed two terms on the USTA’s National Junior Competition Committee. “If you look at the last six or seven years, the level of participation in junior tennis in the United States has fallen off a cliff.”

Martin Blackman, the USTA’s General Manager for Player Development, said another piece of the puzzle will start helping younger male players.

“We want to start giving more comprehensive support to the boys at an earlier stage,” Blackman said. “So I think that’s a focus on the boys and men’s side to start earlier.”

The USTA can’t be blamed entirely for the European takeover of men’s tennis. That’s mostly due to the unlikely simultaneous ascent of the three best players in the modern era. Since 2006, all 55 majors have been won by just seven men, from Europe and South America: Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray, Stan Wawrinka, Martín del Potro and Marin Cilic. Combined, the Europeans Federer, Nadal and Djokovic have won 54 majors since 2003, a total that has never been reached by a trio in tennis history.

John Isner, age 34, remains inside the top 15. Photo: Eduardo Munoz Alvarez/Associated Press

The question is, how do younger players, especially in America, rise up and play tennis better than ever before? Opelka, who is 6-feet-11, wouldn’t win Slam titles just by smashing a serve. But Opelka is more athletic and can run faster than most would expect.

“He’s the real deal,” said coach Rick Macci, who has worked with Opelka. “But overall, young players need more of a package and the movement part. I don’t see it.”

Finding a male player like Gauff is not easy. Grant would like to see more American competitive opportunities so talented athletes don’t need to travel internationally and can get more competition at higher levels. But more than anything, the American men need a spark.

“Basically, the men in the U.S. need someone like Coco,” Patrick Mouratoglou, who coaches Gauff at times. “You need a guide.”
description: It’s been 16 years since Andy Roddick won the U.S. Open. The U.S. men’s Grand Slam drought is likely to continue with no stars on the horizon.
